dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: A 16% drop in marriages in Kazakhstan just this year? That seems like a massive shift.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: A sixteen percent drop in marriages in Kazakhstan just this year? That seems like a massive shift.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: According to the information, approximately 22,500 unions were registered in Kazakhstan in the first three months of this year. This figure represents a 16% decrease (or 4,300 fewer unions) compared to the same period last year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, it's pretty significant. The First Credit Bureau reported only 22,500 unions in the first quarter, which is 4,300 fewer than last year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, it's pretty significant. The First Credit Bureau reported only twenty two thousand, five hundred unions in the first quarter, which is four thousand, three hundred fewer than last year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This was reported by the First Credit Bureau. According to the information, approximately 22,500 unions were registered in Kazakhstan in the first three months of this year.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: But wasn't there a huge dip during COVID? I feel like that might be skewing things.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: But wasn't there a huge dip during COVID? I feel like that might be skewing things.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Well, they actually mention that—this is the lowest since 2014, excluding that weird COVID quarter in 2020.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Well, they actually mention that-this is the lowest since twenty fourteen, excluding that weird COVID quarter in twenty twenty.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: This is the lowest level since the beginning of 2014, excluding the anomaly during the COVID-19 restrictions in the second quarter of 2020 (April to June), when only 16,600 marriages were registered.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Hmm, okay. But are we sure it's not just, like, people delaying weddings or something seasonal?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Hmm, okay. But are we sure it's not just, like, people delaying weddings or something seasonal?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: The data shows it's a real trend though, especially sharp declines in places like Almaty and Turkestan region, down 21 and 19 percent.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: The data shows it's a real trend though, especially sharp declines in places like Almaty and Turkestan region, down twenty one and nineteen percent.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: There was a particularly sharp decrease in marriages in Almaty (down by 21%) and Turkestan region (down by 19%).

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Alright, but why such a steep drop? People still fall in love, right?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Alright, but why such a steep drop? People still fall in love, right?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Psychologists point to a few reasons—like, uh, economic instability and rising costs. Marriage is seen as an expensive step now.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Psychologists point to a few reasons-like, uh, economic instability and rising costs. Marriage is seen as an expensive step now.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Economic instability, rising housing costs, and everyday expenses also play a role, with many people seeing marriage as an expensive step.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: That makes sense, I guess. But isn't part of it just that people are more cautious?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That makes sense, I guess. But isn't part of it just that people are more cautious?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Exactly—they're more mindful about choosing partners, value personal comfort, some even treat civil marriage as a kind of test drive.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Exactly-they're more mindful about choosing partners, value personal comfort, some even treat civil marriage as a kind of test drive.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They believe that for many, the marriage certificate is no longer a priority, as people have become more mindful about choosing a partner, value personal comfort, and increasingly opt for civil marriages as a "test drive" before making serious commitments.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Test drive, huh? So it's not just money; it's also fear? Like, uh, fear of divorce or domestic issues?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Test drive, huh? So it's not just money; it's also fear? Like, uh, fear of divorce or domestic issues?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Yeah, the article mentions growing distrust, emotional immaturity… people worry marriage might actually make things worse.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Yeah, the article mentions growing distrust, emotional immaturity... people worry marriage might actually make things worse.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: The level of distrust in society is growing, and many partners, according to psychologists, demonstrate emotional immaturity. Some have developed the mindset that getting married will only make things worse.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: And what about divorces? If fewer marry, are fewer divorcing too?
dialogue_turns.tts_text: And what about divorces? If fewer marry, are fewer divorcing too?

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: Actually, divorces have dropped as well—from almost 60,000 in 2019 to around 40,000 last year.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Actually, divorces have dropped as well-from almost sixty thousand in twenty nineteen to around forty thousand last year.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: In 2019, there were 59,700 divorces registered nationwide, while in 2023, the number was 40,200.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Wow, so both numbers are down. Maybe it's a broader social shift then, not just pessimism.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Wow, so both numbers are down. Maybe it's a broader social shift then, not just pessimism.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: For sure—global trends play a role too. People prioritize education, career, financial stability first nowadays.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: For sure-global trends play a role too. People prioritize education, career, financial stability first nowadays.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: Following global trends, most people prioritize education and career first, aiming to become financially stable, save for housing, and build a financial cushion.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostA
dialogue_turns.text: Makes you wonder if marriage as an institution is just… evolving, not necessarily declining.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: Makes you wonder if marriage as an institution is just... evolving, not necessarily declining.

dialogue_turns.speaker: HostB
dialogue_turns.text: That's a good way to put it. It's less about the certificate and more about readiness, comfort, those practical and emotional foundations.
dialogue_turns.tts_text: That's a good way to put it. It's less about the certificate and more about readiness, comfort, those practical and emotional foundations.
dialogue_turns.evidence_snippet: They believe that for many, the marriage certificate is no longer a priority, as people have become more mindful about choosing a partner, value personal comfort, and increasingly opt for civil marriages as a "test drive" before making serious commitments.
